questions.text: A 65-year-old man underwent endoscopic perforator vein ligation for chronic venous insufficiency. Two weeks post-surgery, he complains of burning pain and numbness over the lateral aspect of the lower leg extending to the lateral border of the foot. Which nerve is most likely injured? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Sural nerve

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The clinical scenario suggests sural nerve injury following perforator vein surgery. This commonly occurs because:
  • • The sural nerve closely accompanies the small saphenous vein It runs in the posterolateral aspect of the leg During perforator surgery, especially in the lateral calf region, the nerve is at risk The sensory distribution matches the patient's symptoms (lateral leg and foot)
  • • The sural nerve closely accompanies the small saphenous vein
  • • It runs in the posterolateral aspect of the leg
  • • During perforator surgery, especially in the lateral calf region, the nerve is at risk
  • • The sensory distribution matches the patient's symptoms (lateral leg and foot)
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Saphenous nerve:
  • • Option A. Saphenous nerve:
  • • Runs with the great saphenous vein on the medial aspect Supplies sensation to the medial leg and foot More commonly injured during great saphenous vein surgery Symptoms would be on medial, not lateral aspect
  • • Runs with the great saphenous vein on the medial aspect
  • • Supplies sensation to the medial leg and foot
  • • More commonly injured during great saphenous vein surgery
  • • Symptoms would be on medial, not lateral aspect
  • • Option B. Deep peroneal nerve:
  • • Option B. Deep peroneal nerve:
  • • Primarily supplies the first web space Has minimal cutaneous distribution Runs in the anterior compartment Not typically at risk during perforator surgery
  • • Primarily supplies the first web space
  • • Has minimal cutaneous distribution
  • • Runs in the anterior compartment
  • • Not typically at risk during perforator surgery
  • • Option D. Tibial nerve:
  • • Option D. Tibial nerve:
  • • Located deep in the posterior compartment Mixed motor-sensory nerve Would cause more extensive symptoms including motor deficits Not typically injured during endoscopic procedures
  • • Located deep in the posterior compartment
  • • Mixed motor-sensory nerve
  • • Would cause more extensive symptoms including motor deficits
  • • Not typically injured during endoscopic procedures

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anatomical relationship between the sural nerve and small saphenous vein is crucial during vein surgery to prevent iatrogenic injury. The sural nerve:
  • ➤ Runs superficially in the posterolateral leg Is at risk during both open and endoscopic procedures Can cause significant post-operative morbidity if injured Should be identified and protected during perforator ligation
  • ➤ Runs superficially in the posterolateral leg
  • ➤ Is at risk during both open and endoscopic procedures
  • ➤ Can cause significant post-operative morbidity if injured
  • ➤ Should be identified and protected during perforator ligation

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with hard breast lump with breast changes. On examination, there is a hard lump of around 4x3 cm with dimpling of skin and nipple retraction, but no peau d’orange appearance. The skin changes are more prominent when the arms are raised. Which of the following is most likely the diagnosis in this patient? (Twisted question)

options.label: B
options.text: Locally advanced breast cancer with axillary involvement

options.label: C
options.text: Early breast cancer with Cooper's ligament involvement

questions.correct_answer: C. Early breast cancer with Cooper's ligament involvement
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Early breast cancer with Cooper’s ligament involvement

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The most significant finding in this case is skin puckering/dimpling that becomes more prominent with arm movement, along with nipple retraction. This is characteristic of early breast cancer with Cooper's ligament involvement.
  • • When breast cancer involves Cooper's ligaments (fibrous bands that help maintain breast structure), it causes:
  • • Tethering of the skin, leading to dimpling/puckering The changes become more prominent with arm movement May be associated with nipple retraction Usually seen in early stages before lymphatic obstruction occurs
  • • Tethering of the skin, leading to dimpling/puckering
  • • The changes become more prominent with arm movement
  • • May be associated with nipple retraction
  • • Usually seen in early stages before lymphatic obstruction occurs
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Inflammatory breast cancer:
  • • Option A. Inflammatory breast cancer:
  • • Presents with peau d'orange appearance, skin erythema, and warmth Caused by dermal lymphatic invasion Would show more dramatic skin changes than just dimpling
  • • Presents with peau d'orange appearance, skin erythema, and warmth
  • • Caused by dermal lymphatic invasion
  • • Would show more dramatic skin changes than just dimpling
  • • Option B. Locally advanced breast cancer with axillary involvement:
  • • Option B. Locally advanced breast cancer with axillary involvement:
  • • Would typically present with peau d'orange appearance Associated with fixed axillary lymphadenopathy Represents a more advanced stage than simple skin dimpling
  • • Would typically present with peau d'orange appearance
  • • Associated with fixed axillary lymphadenopathy
  • • Represents a more advanced stage than simple skin dimpling
  • • Option D. Ductal ectasia with periductal mastitis:
  • • Option D. Ductal ectasia with periductal mastitis:
  • • Can cause nipple retraction Usually presents with nipple discharge Doesn't typically cause skin dimpling/puckering
  • • Can cause nipple retraction
  • • Usually presents with nipple discharge
  • • Doesn't typically cause skin dimpling/puckering

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Early breast cancer involving Cooper's ligaments presents with skin dimpling/puckering that becomes more prominent with arm movement. This is different from peau d'orange appearance, which occurs in more advanced cases due to lymphatic obstruction. Understanding these differences helps in staging breast cancer and determining appropriate management strategies.

questions.text: Inferior thyroid artery most commonly passes anterior to which of the following structures? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Common carotid artery

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The inferior thyroid artery, after arising from the thyrocervical trunk, has a characteristic course where it ascends anterior to the medial border of scalenus anterior, then turns medially below the sixth cervical transverse process. In its course to the thyroid gland, it consistently passes anterior to the common carotid artery before reaching the lower pole of the thyroid gland.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Vertebral artery : The vertebral artery ascends through the transverse foramina of cervical vertebrae. The inferior thyroid artery does not have a consistent anterior relationship with the vertebral artery.
  • • Option A. Vertebral artery
  • • Option C. Recurrent laryngeal nerve : The relationship between the inferior thyroid artery and recurrent laryngeal nerve is highly variable. The nerve may pass anterior, posterior, or between branches of the artery. This variability is surgically significant during thyroid operations.
  • • Option C. Recurrent laryngeal nerve
  • • Option D. Vagus nerve : The vagus nerve typically runs posterior to the common carotid artery in the carotid sheath. The inferior thyroid artery does not have a consistent anterior relationship with the vagus nerve.
  • • Option D. Vagus nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Course and relationships of the inferior thyroid artery is crucial for thyroid surgery. While its origin from the thyrocervical trunk is consistent, its most reliable anatomical relationship is passing anterior to the common carotid artery. The variable relationship with the recurrent laryngeal nerve is particularly important to recognize to prevent nerve injury during thyroid procedures.

questions.text: A person after neck surgery develops difficulty in rotary movements of head and inability to turn head to opposite side. Which structure is most likely to be damaged? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Accessory nerve

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The accessory nerve (CN XI) innervates both the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles In this case, the focus is on sternocleidomastoid dysfunction Damage leads to weakness in head rotation to opposite side Post-surgical injury is a common cause of accessory nerve damage
  • • The accessory nerve (CN XI) innervates both the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles
  • • In this case, the focus is on sternocleidomastoid dysfunction
  • • Damage leads to weakness in head rotation to opposite side
  • • Post-surgical injury is a common cause of accessory nerve damage
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Long thoracic nerve:
  • • Option A. Long thoracic nerve:
  • • Innervates only the serratus anterior muscle Damage causes winging of scapula Not involved in neck movements or head rotation
  • • Innervates only the serratus anterior muscle
  • • Damage causes winging of scapula
  • • Not involved in neck movements or head rotation
  • • Option B. Deltoid muscle:
  • • Option B. Deltoid muscle:
  • • Responsible for shoulder abduction Innervated by axillary nerve (C5, C6) Not involved in neck movements
  • • Responsible for shoulder abduction
  • • Innervated by axillary nerve (C5, C6)
  • • Not involved in neck movements
  • • Option D. Sternocleidomastoid muscle:
  • • Option D. Sternocleidomastoid muscle:
  • • While this is the affected muscle, the question asks about the damaged structure It's the end organ, not the source of dysfunction The nerve supply (CN XI) is the actual damaged structure
  • • While this is the affected muscle, the question asks about the damaged structure
  • • It's the end organ, not the source of dysfunction
  • • The nerve supply (CN XI) is the actual damaged structure

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The accessory nerve plays a crucial role in head rotation and shoulder elevation. Its injury, often seen during neck surgeries, presents with impaired head-turning to the opposite side and shoulder droop. Recognizing this clinical scenario is essential for diagnosing and managing post-surgical complications.

questions.text: Where is the maximal blood supply for bone growth and remodeling present? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Metaphysis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The metaphysis has the richest blood supply in long bones It contains numerous nutrient vessels and sinusoidal capillaries This rich vascularity supports active bone remodeling and growth The metaphyseal region is often called the "transformation zone" due to its high metabolic activity
  • • The metaphysis has the richest blood supply in long bones
  • • It contains numerous nutrient vessels and sinusoidal capillaries
  • • This rich vascularity supports active bone remodeling and growth
  • • The metaphyseal region is often called the "transformation zone" due to its high metabolic activity
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Epiphysis:
  • • Option A. Epiphysis:
  • • Has relatively less vascularity compared to metaphysis Blood supply mainly from epiphyseal arteries Not the primary site of active bone remodeling
  • • Has relatively less vascularity compared to metaphysis
  • • Blood supply mainly from epiphyseal arteries
  • • Not the primary site of active bone remodeling
  • • Option C. Diaphysis:
  • • Option C. Diaphysis:
  • • Primarily supplied by single nutrient artery Has less vascularity compared to metaphysis Main function is structural support rather than active growth
  • • Primarily supplied by single nutrient artery
  • • Has less vascularity compared to metaphysis
  • • Main function is structural support rather than active growth
  • • Option D. Epiphyseal plate:
  • • Option D. Epiphyseal plate:
  • • While crucial for longitudinal growth, it's actually avascular Relies on diffusion from epiphyseal and metaphyseal vessels Cartilaginous in nature, lacking direct blood supply
  • • While crucial for longitudinal growth, it's actually avascular
  • • Relies on diffusion from epiphyseal and metaphyseal vessels
  • • Cartilaginous in nature, lacking direct blood supply

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The metaphysis is the most vascularized region of a long bone during growth, supporting the demands of the epiphyseal plate. This high blood supply is crucial for growth, remodeling, and repair in children and adolescents. Understanding this is important for diagnosing growth-related bone diseases.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is not involved in taste sensation? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Trigeminal nerve

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The trigeminal nerve (CN V) has no role in taste sensation It provides general sensory innervation to the anterior 2/3rd of tongue (touch, pain, temperature) While it contributes to oral sensation, it does not carry taste fibers It's a mixed nerve but lacks special visceral afferent (taste) fibers
  • • The trigeminal nerve (CN V) has no role in taste sensation
  • • It provides general sensory innervation to the anterior 2/3rd of tongue (touch, pain, temperature)
  • • While it contributes to oral sensation, it does not carry taste fibers
  • • It's a mixed nerve but lacks special visceral afferent (taste) fibers
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Facial nerve:
  • • Option B. Facial nerve:
  • • CN VII carries taste from anterior 2/3rd of tongue via chorda tympani Also carries taste from soft palate Contains special visceral afferent fibers for taste
  • • CN VII carries taste from anterior 2/3rd of tongue via chorda tympani
  • • Also carries taste from soft palate
  • • Contains special visceral afferent fibers for taste
  • • Option C. Glossopharyngeal nerve:
  • • Option C. Glossopharyngeal nerve:
  • • CN IX carries taste from posterior 1/3rd of tongue Essential for taste perception in circumvallate papillae Major contributor to bitter taste sensation
  • • CN IX carries taste from posterior 1/3rd of tongue
  • • Essential for taste perception in circumvallate papillae
  • • Major contributor to bitter taste sensation
  • • Option D. Vagus nerve:
  • • Option D. Vagus nerve:
  • • CN X carries taste from epiglottis and pharynx Contributes to taste sensation via its pharyngeal branches Also carries taste from small area behind circumvallate papillae
  • • CN X carries taste from epiglottis and pharynx
  • • Contributes to taste sensation via its pharyngeal branches
  • • Also carries taste from small area behind circumvallate papillae

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Taste sensation is mediated by cranial nerves VII, IX, and X, while the trigeminal nerve is responsible for general somatic sensations and has no involvement in taste perception. Understanding the specific roles of cranial nerves is essential in neurological assessment and diagnosis.

questions.text: A patient presented with abdominal pain for 10 days with a history of continuous fever and bradycardia after frequently consuming meals from street vendors. Which test can be done in the patient to confirm the diagnosis? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Widal test

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In cases of typhoid fever, the Widal test is a serological assay used to detect antibodies against Salmonella typhi antigens (O and H antigens). While blood cultures are most effective in the early stages of the disease (first week), the Widal test becomes more reliable after the first week of illness when the antibody titers rise. In this patient, who has been experiencing symptoms for 10 days, the Widal test is the most appropriate diagnostic tool to confirm typhoid fever. It helps in identifying the immune response to the infection, thereby aiding in accurate diagnosis and timely treatment.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Blood culture: Blood cultures are highly sensitive in the first week of typhoid fever but their sensitivity decreases after this period. Since the patient has been symptomatic for 10 days, the yield of blood cultures would be lower compared to serological tests like the Widal test.
  • • Option B. Blood culture:
  • • Option C. Urine culture: Urine cultures for Salmonella typhi are generally more useful in the later stages of the disease or in chronic carriers. They are not the first-line diagnostic test for acute presentations of typhoid fever.
  • • Option C. Urine culture:
  • • Option D. Stool culture: Stool cultures can be positive in the second and subsequent weeks of the illness and are useful for identifying carriers of the bacteria. However, they are less sensitive in the acute phase compared to the Widal test after the first week.
  • • Option D. Stool culture:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding the appropriate diagnostic tests for typhoid fever based on the duration of symptoms is crucial. Blood cultures are preferred in the early phase (first week), while serological tests like the Widal test become more reliable after the first week. Recognizing the timing of symptom onset aids in selecting the most effective diagnostic method for accurate and timely management.

questions.text: A patient with recurrent respiratory infections presents with fever, hemolytic anemia, and meningitis. There is a deficiency in opsonizing antibodies against encapsulated bacteria. The likely cause can be: (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Haemophilus influenzae

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Haemophilus influenzae is an encapsulated bacterium that frequently causes respiratory tract infections, meningitis, and sepsis, especially in individuals with impaired opsonization. Opsonizing antibodies, particularly IgG against the bacterial capsule, are crucial for effective phagocytosis and clearance of encapsulated organisms. A deficiency in these antibodies compromises the immune system's ability to target and eliminate Haemophilus influenzae, leading to recurrent infections characterized by fever, hemolytic anemia, and meningitis. This clinical presentation aligns with the patient's history of recurrent respiratory infections and the specific immunological deficiency.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): CMV is a viral infection that primarily affects immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV/AIDS or transplant recipients. It typically presents with symptoms like fever, fatigue, and mononucleosis-like syndrome but is not directly associated with deficiencies in opsonizing antibodies or recurrent bacterial infections.
  • • Option A. CMV (Cytomegalovirus):
  • • Option B. Klebsiella pneumoniae: While Klebsiella pneumoniae is an important cause of pneumonia, especially in individuals with alcoholism, diabetes, or those who are immunocompromised, it is not specifically linked to deficiencies in opsonizing antibodies against encapsulated bacteria. Klebsiella infections are more related to impaired barrier defenses and other aspects of the immune response.
  • • Option B. Klebsiella pneumoniae:
  • • Option C. Neisseria meningitidis: Neisseria meningitidis is another encapsulated bacterium that causes meningitis and meningococcemia. However, susceptibility to Neisseria infections is more closely associated with deficiencies in the membrane attack complex (MAC) of the complement system (components C5-C9) rather than deficiencies in opsonizing antibodies.
  • • Option C. Neisseria meningitidis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Deficiencies in opsonizing antibodies against encapsulated bacteria, such as IgG against the bacterial capsule, predispose individuals to recurrent infections with organisms like Haemophilus influenzae. Recognizing the link between specific immunological defects and their associated pathogens is essential for accurate diagnosis and effective management of recurrent bacterial infections.

questions.text: A West African healthcare worker presents with fever, hemorrhagic manifestations, and acute renal failure. What can be the most likely diagnosis? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ebola virus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Ebola virus disease is prevalent in West Africa and is associated with severe hemorrhagic fever. Healthcare workers are at increased risk of exposure due to their contact with infected patients. The clinical presentation often includes fever, hemorrhagic manifestations (such as bleeding gums, petechiae, and internal bleeding), and can progress to acute renal failure. These symptoms align with the patient's presentation, making Ebola virus the most likely diagnosis in this context.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Zika virus: Zika virus is primarily transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes and is associated with symptoms like fever, rash, joint pain, and conjunctivitis. It is not typically associated with hemorrhagic manifestations or acute renal failure.
  • • Option A. Zika virus:
  • • Option B. Nipah virus: Nipah virus is transmitted from fruit bats and can cause encephalitis and respiratory symptoms. While it is severe, it is more common in South Asia and does not typically present with hemorrhagic symptoms or acute renal failure as primary features.
  • • Option B. Nipah virus:
  • • Option C. Malaria: Malaria, caused by Plasmodium species, presents with fever, chills, and flu-like symptoms. Severe forms can lead to complications like cerebral malaria and acute kidney injury, but hemorrhagic manifestations are not characteristic features of malaria.
  • • Option C. Malaria:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ebola virus should be considered in patients from endemic regions, especially healthcare workers with exposure, presenting with fever and hemorrhagic symptoms. Recognizing the clinical features and understanding the transmission risks are crucial for timely diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A female from Himachal Pradesh presented with H/O thorn prick, a year back has a verrucous lesion in the skin with the following microscopic findings. Identify the agent? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Chromoblastomycosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chromoblastomycosis is identified by its characteristic histopathological features, including granulomatous lesions with dark sclerotic bodies (Medlar or copper penny bodies), and is caused by various dematiaceous fungi. The clinical history of a thorn prick and the verrucous lesion further support this diagnosis.

questions.text: Multiple abscesses with discharging sinuses, demonstrating sulphur granules in pus, are caused by: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Actinomyces

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Actinomycosis, particularly its cervicofacial form, is characterized by the formation of abscesses that discharge pus containing sulfur granules. This hallmark feature helps in diagnosing the disease, which requires prolonged antibiotic therapy due to its chronic and indurative nature.

questions.text: (1-3)-B-D glucan assay cannot be used in? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Invasive cryptococcosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The (1-3)-β-D-glucan assay is not useful for diagnosing invasive cryptococcosis as it does not detect the major components of the Cryptococcus capsule.

questions.text: A patient presents with a mobile, warm to touch nodule in the neck. On the anaerobic culture of the biopsy material from this swelling, it showed colonies as shown in the image which had gram-positive branching rods on staining. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this condition? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Penicillin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Penicillin is the drug of choice for treating actinomycete infections, particularly in cervicofacial cases presenting with nodules and characteristic colonies. Prolonged antibiotic therapy is necessary, and surgical intervention may be required for chronic lesions.

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice for neurosyphilis? (NEET PG 2019)

options.label: B
options.text: FTA-ABS- Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption test

questions.correct_answer: A. Venereal disease research laboratory (VDRL) test
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Venereal disease research laboratory (VDRL) test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The CSF-VDRL test, despite its low sensitivity, remains the gold standard for the diagnosis of neurosyphilis due to its high specificity when positive. It is crucial in the diagnostic process for patients with suspected syphilis infection of the central nervous system, helping guide appropriate treatment and management.

questions.text: Vesicular rash is seen in? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.correct_answer: A. Hand, foot, and mouth disease
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hand, foot, and mouth disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vesicular rash is specifically seen in Hand, foot, and mouth disease, which is caused by Coxsackie A virus.

questions.text: Drug resistance is seen in which of the following STDs: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Gonorrhea

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neisseria gonorrhoeae, the causative agent of gonorrhea, has developed resistance to multiple antibiotics, including penicillin and fluoroquinolones, making third-generation cephalosporins the current treatment of choice.

questions.text: Which of the following is not involved in urethritis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) H.ducreyi

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Urethritis is classified into two types:
  • ➤ Gonococcal urethritis - caused by Neisseria gonorrhea. Non-gonococcal urethritis - caused by: Chlamydia trachomatis (most common ) Ureaplasma urealyticum Adenovirus Haemophilus vaginalis Mycoplasma genitalium Tricomonas vaginalis (rare) Herpes simplex virus (rare)
  • ➤ Gonococcal urethritis - caused by Neisseria gonorrhea.
  • ➤ Non-gonococcal urethritis - caused by: Chlamydia trachomatis (most common ) Ureaplasma urealyticum Adenovirus Haemophilus vaginalis Mycoplasma genitalium Tricomonas vaginalis (rare) Herpes simplex virus (rare)
  • ➤ Chlamydia trachomatis (most common ) Ureaplasma urealyticum Adenovirus Haemophilus vaginalis Mycoplasma genitalium Tricomonas vaginalis (rare) Herpes simplex virus (rare)
  • ➤ Chlamydia trachomatis (most common )
  • ➤ Chlamydia trachomatis (most common
  • ➤ Ureaplasma urealyticum
  • ➤ Adenovirus
  • ➤ Haemophilus vaginalis
  • ➤ Mycoplasma genitalium
  • ➤ Tricomonas vaginalis (rare)
  • ➤ Herpes simplex virus (rare)

questions.text: The strict anaerobe among the following is: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Prevotella

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prevotella species are strict anaerobes, thriving in oxygen-free environments, and are part of the normal flora of the oral, vaginal, and gut microbiota. They can be involved in various anaerobic infections, particularly of the respiratory tract.

questions.text: A farmer suffered from a subcutaneous wound on the dorsum of the foot which later involved the subcutaneous tissue and produced a discharging ulcer. Microscopic examination of the discharge showed gram-positive filamentous rods with branching. The organism responsible is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Nocardia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases involving subcutaneous infections with gram-positive filamentous rods and branching, consider Nocardia as the responsible organism, particularly in the context of actinomycetoma.

questions.text: All of the following is true regarding scrub typhus except: ( INICET MAY 2020)

options.label: C
options.text: Produces NLF producing colonies in MacConkey agar

questions.correct_answer: C. Produces NLF producing colonies in MacConkey agar
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Produces NLF producing colonies in MacConkey agar

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Orientia tsutsugamushi, the causative agent of scrub typhus, is an obligate intracellular bacterium that cannot grow on cell-free media like MacConkey agar. It requires living cells for its cultivation. Scrub typhus is transmitted by chiggers and features symptoms such as fever, lymphadenopathy, and a characteristic eschar at the site of the bite. Humans are accidental hosts for this infection.

questions.text: Vaccine can be prepared against which of the following proteins of the virus? ( INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) L1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A man presents with a history of dysuria and urethral discharge after having unprotected sexual intercourse. Gram-staining of the purulent discharge is seen in the following image. What is the treatment of choice for this infection? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ceftriaxone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For uncomplicated gonorrhea, especially cases presenting with urethral discharge and identified intracellular gram-negative diplococci, Ceftriaxone remains the treatment of choice. This choice reflects current guidelines that prioritize efficacy and resistance profiles in managing sexually transmitted infections.

questions.text: The following slide is given as a spotter in your microbiology practical examination. Identify the following organism? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Mycobacteria

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mycobacterium tuberculosis, appear as pink bacilli on a blue background when stained with Ziehl-Neelsen stain due to their acid-fast properties. They have a high lipid content in their cell walls, which retains the carbol fuchsin dye even after treatment with acid-alcohol, a hallmark of acid-fast organisms.
  • ➤ Mycobacterium tuberculosis, appear as pink bacilli on a blue background when stained with Ziehl-Neelsen stain due to their acid-fast properties.
  • ➤ They have a high lipid content in their cell walls, which retains the carbol fuchsin dye even after treatment with acid-alcohol, a hallmark of acid-fast organisms.

questions.text: Cutaneous larva migrans is most commonly caused by which organism? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ancylostoma braziliense

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ancylostoma braziliense is the primary cause of cutaneous larva migrans, a condition where the migration of hookworm larvae in the skin results in distinctive creeping eruptions. This condition is a reminder of the zoonotic potential of certain parasites and underscores the importance of preventive measures, especially in areas where pets are likely to be infected.

questions.text: A patient was sputum negative for tuberculosis, but chest X-ray was suggestive of tuberculosis. Which is the next step according to RNTCP? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) CBNAAT

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For patients with negative sputum smears but chest X-ray findings suggestive of TB, CBNAAT is the recommended next diagnostic step under RNTCP guidelines.

questions.text: In which of the following situations will you use a sanitizer? (INICET NOV 2020) Before examining the patient After examining the patient After touching the patient's surroundings Hands are visibly soiled
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) A, B and C only

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Healthcare personnel should use hand sanitizer before and after examining a patient and after touching the patient's surroundings. However, when hands are visibly soiled, hand hygiene should be performed using soap and water instead of a sanitizer.

questions.text: Contact based isolation is employed for which of the following diseases? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) MRSA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The three categories of transmission-based precautions include:
  • ➤ Contact- based isolation is used for infections, diseases, or germs that are spread by touching the patient or items in the room. Examples include MRSA, VRE, diarrheal illnesses, open wounds, and RSV. Droplet-based isolation is employed for diphtheria and mumps. Airborne precautions are required to protect against conditions like measles, severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), varicella (chickenpox), and Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • ➤ Contact- based isolation is used for infections, diseases, or germs that are spread by touching the patient or items in the room. Examples include MRSA, VRE, diarrheal illnesses, open wounds, and RSV.
  • ➤ Contact- based isolation
  • ➤ Droplet-based isolation is employed for diphtheria and mumps.
  • ➤ Droplet-based isolation
  • ➤ Airborne precautions are required to protect against conditions like measles, severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), varicella (chickenpox), and Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • ➤ Airborne precautions

questions.text: A forest worker developed skin lesions over the forearm, which initially started as macules but then became nodules. Histology of the nodules shows the following findings. Which of the following is true regarding this condition? (INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: The organism does not invade underlying fascia, tendon, muscle, or joints.

options.label: B
options.text: Angioinvasion is common, especially in people with hemolytic anemia.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a dimorphic organism, and yeast forms are seen in clinical sample.

options.label: D
options.text: These bodies are formed by engulfment of the dead fungi by the macrophages.

questions.correct_answer: A. The organism does not invade underlying fascia, tendon, muscle, or joints.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) The organism does not invade underlying fascia, tendon, muscle, or joints.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chromoblastomycosis is characterized by skin lesions containing sclerotic bodies (Medlar bodies) and does not typically invade deeper tissues such as fascia, tendons, muscles, or joints.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the likely organism shown in the image below?

options.label: B

options.label: D
options.text: Severe infection is seen if CD4 count is below 900

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Most commonly affects lungs

questions.text: A 30-year-old HIV-positive patient presented with a chronic history of watery diarrhea. Histopathology of the duodenum is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the causative organism? ( NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Giardia lamblia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Giardia lamblia is a significant cause of diarrheal disease, especially in settings where water or food might be contaminated. Its unique trophozoites are diagnosable through histopathology, emphasizing the need for awareness of water and food hygiene to prevent its transmission. Treatment typically involves specific anti-protozoal medications, and addressing it effectively is crucial in immunocompromised patients to prevent prolonged symptoms and nutritional deficiencies.

questions.text: In a patient in the ICU, an infection in the central venous catheter is noted. Staining showed a gram-positive oval-shaped organism that reproduces by budding. Identify the organism. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Candida

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Candida is an oval-shaped yeast that reproduces by budding and is a common cause of catheter-associated infections in ICU patients.

questions.text: False about the Ebola virus is: ( INICET MAY 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Transmitted by mosquito

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ The Ebola virus is a filovirus transmitted through direct contact with the bodily fluids of infected individuals or animals, not by mosquitoes. Fruit bats are the most likely natural reservoir, and nosocomial transmission is a known route of spread.

questions.text: The Epstein-Barr virus interacts with B cells via which of the following? ( INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) CD21

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infects B cells by binding to the CD21 receptor, which is the primary entry point for the virus into these cells.
  • ➤ Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infects B cells by binding to the CD21 receptor, which is the primary entry point for the virus into these cells.

questions.text: Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is involved in the hyperacute rejection of renal transplants? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The following are true about chancroid: (INICET NOV 2020) School of fish appearance Bleeds on touch Painful Groove sign

questions.text: Which of the following organisms follow a bird-arthropod-human transmission route? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Japanese encephalitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The transmission cycles of diseases like Japanese encephalitis is crucial for implementing effective public health measures. In the case of JE, controlling mosquito populations and minimizing human exposure to mosquito bites, especially in areas where birds are present, are key strategies in preventing the disease.

questions.text: Which type of cartilage is the most prevalent? (NEET PG 2016 )
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hyaline cartilage

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Hyaline cartilage is the correct answer as it is indeed the most abundant type of cartilage in the human body. This type of cartilage is present in numerous locations throughout the body, including the larynx, trachea, ends of ribs, and covering the ends of bones where they form joints. Its extensive presence in various joints and supportive structures, its role in the growth and development of long bones (epiphyseal plates), and its ability to resist compressive forces make it notably prevalent. The characteristic homogenous, glassy appearance of hyaline cartilage, along with typically having 2-4 chondrocytes per lacuna and being covered by perichondrium (except at articular surfaces), further identifies it as the most common cartilage type.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Elastic cartilage : Incorrect, as it is less common and primarily found in flexible areas such as the ear, epiglottis, and parts of the larynx.
  • • Option
  • • B. Elastic cartilage
  • • Option C. Fibrocartilage : Incorrect, as it is found in specific areas that require a great deal of strength and shock absorption, such as intervertebral discs and menisci, and is not as widespread as hyaline cartilage.
  • • Option
  • • C. Fibrocartilage
  • • Option D. None of the above : Incorrect, as hyaline cartilage is extensively documented as the most prevalent type of cartilage.
  • • Option
  • • D. None of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hyaline cartilage is the most abundant type of cartilage found in the body, known for its widespread presence in various supportive and articulatory structures.

questions.text: During climbing the staircase, a person suddenly fell & a sharp object hit on his neck. After the injury, the patient is unable to shrug/elevate the shoulder & he is having difficulty in turning his head. What structure is most likely to be damaged? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Spinal accessory nerve

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The spinal accessory nerve (11th cranial nerve) innervates both the trapezius and sternocleidomastoid muscles. The trapezius muscle is responsible for the elevation or shrugging of the shoulder, while the sternocleidomastoid muscle is responsible for turning the head. Injury to the spinal accessory nerve results in an inability to perform these actions, which matches the patient's symptoms of being unable to shrug/elevate the shoulder and having difficulty turning the head. Therefore, the most likely structure damaged in this case is the spinal accessory nerve.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Long thoracic nerve: This nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle, which is responsible for the protraction and upward rotation of the scapula. Damage to this nerve causes winging of the scapula, not an inability to shrug the shoulder or turn the head.
  • • Option A. Long thoracic nerve:
  • • Option C. Sternocleidomastoid: While the sternocleidomastoid muscle is indeed involved in turning the head, its dysfunction alone would not explain the inability to shrug the shoulder. The issue lies with the nerve that innervates both the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.
  • • Option C. Sternocleidomastoid:
  • • Option D. Deltoid: This muscle is innervated by the axillary nerve and is responsible for shoulder abduction. Damage to the deltoid or axillary nerve would cause difficulty in shoulder abduction, not in shrugging the shoulder or turning the head.
  • • Option D. Deltoid:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The spinal accessory nerve (11th cranial nerve) is responsible for innervating the trapezius and sternocleidomastoid muscles, which are essential for shrugging the shoulder and turning the head, respectively.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the image given below: ( NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Fornix

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fornix is a C-shaped bundle of nerve fibers that acts as a major output tract from the hippocampus to the mammillary bodies and then onto the thalamus. In the midsagittal section, the fornix is seen as an arching structure that lies inferior to the corpus callosum, the massive fiber tract connecting the two cerebral hemispheres. The body of the fornix travels anteriorly and inferiorly, eventually dividing into left and right columns which curve downward in front of the thalamus.
  • ➤ Fornix

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented with a positive Trendelenburg test. Identify the nerve injured: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Superior gluteal nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ The superior gluteal nerve's role in stabilizing the pelvis during gait is critical. A positive Trendelenburg test indicates an inability to maintain pelvic stability due to weakness or paralysis of the gluteus medius and minimus muscles, typically stemming from an injury to the superior gluteal nerve. This understanding is essential for diagnosing and managing conditions related to hip stability and gait abnormalities.

questions.text: Identify the type of cartilage shown in the image below:(NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Elastic cartilage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the shown congenital anomaly in which the intestinal loops are present outside the abdominal cavity covered by amniotic membrane. (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Omphalocele

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The image depicts a congenital anomaly known as omphalocele. This condition is characterized by the presence of intestinal loops and sometimes other abdominal organs outside the abdominal cavity. These organs are covered by a transparent sac composed of the amniotic membrane, peritoneum, and Wharton's jelly.
  • • Omphalocele Characteristics: In omphalocele, the herniated organs protrude through the umbilical ring and are covered by the amniotic membrane. This condition is associated with various other congenital anomalies and syndromes.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Gastroschisis : This is incorrect. In gastroschisis, the intestines protrude through a defect in the abdominal wall, usually to the right of the umbilical cord, without any covering membrane. The exposed intestines are directly exposed to the amniotic fluid, which distinguishes it from omphalocele.
  • • Option A. Gastroschisis
  • • Option C. Omphalocele with enteric cyst : This is incorrect. While an omphalocele can be associated with various anomalies, the specific mention of an enteric cyst is not a standard characteristic of typical omphalocele presentations.
  • • Option C. Omphalocele with enteric cyst
  • • Option D. Gastroschisis with enteric cyst: This is incorrect. Gastroschisis involves exposed intestines without a covering membrane. The presence of an enteric cyst does not align with the typical presentation of gastroschisis.
  • • Option D. Gastroschisis with enteric cyst:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Omphalocele is a congenital anomaly where the intestines and possibly other organs protrude through the umbilical ring, covered by the amniotic membrane. This differentiates it from gastroschisis, where the intestines are exposed without a covering membrane.

questions.text: Post fertilization, implantation begins to take place on? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Day 5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Implantation typically begins around the 5th to 6th day after fertilization, with Day 5 often representing the initial attachment of the blastocyst to the uterine lining. If Day 6 is not an option, choose the next closest day, which is Day 5.

questions.text: Middle radioulnar joint is a type of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Syndesmosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The middle radioulnar joint is classified as a syndesmosis, which is a type of fibrous joint connected by a sheet of fibrous tissue, such as the interosseous membrane.

questions.text: Blood supply for the red shaded area in the given image is a branch of which artery? ( INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Vertebral artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA), which is a branch of the vertebral artery, supplies the lateral medulla. Damage to this artery can result in lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome).

questions.text: Which marked structure causes lateral rotation, flexion, and abduction at the hip joint, along with flexion at the knee joint? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. 4

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The muscle marked in the image are:
  • • The muscle marked in the image are:
  • • Option A. 1- Rectus femoris
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. 2- Vastus lateralis
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C . 3- Adductor longus
  • • Option C
  • • Option D . 4- Sartorius
  • • Option D
  • • Sartorius is involved in lateral rotation, flexion, and abduction at the hip joint, and flexion at the knee. The structure marked '4' is sartorius.
  • • The sartorius muscle is a long, thin muscle that runs down the front of the thigh. It is the body's longest muscle and is sometimes referred to as the tailor muscle because of the position that tailors often adopt while working. The sartorius muscle originates from the anterior superior iliac spine and the upper half of the notch below it, and runs obliquely across the thigh to insert into the superior aspect of the medial surface of the tibial shaft near the tibial tuberosity. It joins the aponeurosis of the gracilis and semitendinosus muscles to form the pes anserinus.
  • • The sartorius muscle is responsible for several actions, including flexion, abduction, and lateral rotation of the thigh, as well as flexion of the leg. Because of its location and actions, it is involved in many activities that require movement of the lower limb, such as walking, running, and climbing stairs.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Muscles of the anterior compartment of thigh (spinal segments in bold are the major segments innervating the muscle)
  • ➤ Muscles of the anterior compartment of thigh (spinal segments in bold are the major segments innervating the muscle)

questions.text: The green line corresponds to which vertebral level?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) L5

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The green line shown in the image corresponds to the trans-tubercular plane, which passes through the L5 vertebral level. The abdominal planes are used as anatomical landmarks to describe the location of structures and features within the abdomen. The important horizontal planes include:
  • • Transpyloric plane: Passes through the lower border of L1 vertebra. Subcostal plane: Passes through the upper border of L3 vertebra. Transtubercular plane: Passes through the upper border of L5 vertebra, as seen in the image.
  • • Transpyloric plane: Passes through the lower border of L1 vertebra.
  • • Transpyloric plane:
  • • Subcostal plane: Passes through the upper border of L3 vertebra.
  • • Subcostal plane:
  • • Transtubercular plane: Passes through the upper border of L5 vertebra, as seen in the image.
  • • Transtubercular plane:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. L1: This corresponds to the transpyloric plane, which is higher up in the abdomen.
  • • Option A. L1:
  • • Option B. L3: This corresponds to the subcostal plane, located midway between the transpyloric and transtubercular planes.
  • • Option B. L3:
  • • Option D. T12: This vertebral level is not associated with the horizontal planes typically used in abdominal anatomy and is located in the thoracic region.
  • • Option D. T12:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The transtubercular plane passes through the L5 vertebral level, and it is a key anatomical landmark in the lower abdomen.

questions.text: Dorsal mesentery of esophagus forms which component of the diaphragm? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)

options.label: D
options.text: From medial to lateral part of diaphragm

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Crura

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The diaphragm is a muscular and tendinous structure that separates the thoracic cavity from the abdominal cavity. It develops from several embryonic structures, including the septum transversum, pleuroperitoneal membranes, dorsal mesentery of the esophagus, and body wall musculature.
  • • Developmental Components of the Diaphragm: Septum Transversum: This forms the central tendon of the diaphragm. Pleuroperitoneal Membranes: These contribute to the posterolateral portions of the diaphragm. Body Wall: Contributes to the peripheral muscular portions of the diaphragm. Dorsal Mesentery of the Esophagus: This forms the crura of the diaphragm. The crura are muscular structures that extend from the lumbar vertebrae to the central tendon of the diaphragm and provide support to the esophageal opening. Role of Crura: The crura of the diaphragm are essential for anchoring the diaphragm to the vertebral column and aiding in the function of the esophageal hiatus. They form from the right and left sides of the dorsal mesentery of the esophagus, which are critical for maintaining the anatomical integrity and function of the diaphragm.
  • • Developmental Components of the Diaphragm: Septum Transversum: This forms the central tendon of the diaphragm. Pleuroperitoneal Membranes: These contribute to the posterolateral portions of the diaphragm. Body Wall: Contributes to the peripheral muscular portions of the diaphragm. Dorsal Mesentery of the Esophagus: This forms the crura of the diaphragm. The crura are muscular structures that extend from the lumbar vertebrae to the central tendon of the diaphragm and provide support to the esophageal opening.
  • • Developmental Components of the Diaphragm:
  • • Septum Transversum: This forms the central tendon of the diaphragm. Pleuroperitoneal Membranes: These contribute to the posterolateral portions of the diaphragm. Body Wall: Contributes to the peripheral muscular portions of the diaphragm. Dorsal Mesentery of the Esophagus: This forms the crura of the diaphragm. The crura are muscular structures that extend from the lumbar vertebrae to the central tendon of the diaphragm and provide support to the esophageal opening.
  • • Septum Transversum: This forms the central tendon of the diaphragm.
  • • Pleuroperitoneal Membranes: These contribute to the posterolateral portions of the diaphragm.
  • • Body Wall: Contributes to the peripheral muscular portions of the diaphragm.
  • • Dorsal Mesentery of the Esophagus: This forms the crura of the diaphragm. The crura are muscular structures that extend from the lumbar vertebrae to the central tendon of the diaphragm and provide support to the esophageal opening.
  • • Role of Crura: The crura of the diaphragm are essential for anchoring the diaphragm to the vertebral column and aiding in the function of the esophageal hiatus. They form from the right and left sides of the dorsal mesentery of the esophagus, which are critical for maintaining the anatomical integrity and function of the diaphragm.
  • • Role of Crura:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Pleuroperitoneal membrane: This is incorrect. The pleuroperitoneal membranes contribute to the posterolateral parts of the diaphragm but not to the crura.
  • • Option A. Pleuroperitoneal membrane:
  • • Option C. Septum transversum: This is incorrect. The septum transversum primarily forms the central tendon of the diaphragm.
  • • Option C. Septum transversum:
  • • Option D. From medial to lateral part of diaphragm: This option is not specific and does not accurately describe any particular component formed by the dorsal mesentery of the esophagus.
  • • Option D. From medial to lateral part of diaphragm:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The crura of the diaphragm develop from the dorsal mesentery of the esophagus and play a vital role in anchoring the diaphragm and forming the esophageal hiatus.

questions.explanation:
Ans.

questions.text: A person had a fall on an outstretched hand. He presented with pain and swelling at the base of the thumb. Which structure is most likely to be injured? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Scaphoid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which among the following statements is true regarding the course of the mandibular nerve? (INICET NOV 2022) Auriculotemporal nerve is a branch from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it emerges from behind the temporomandibular joint. Buccal branch is a branch from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it emerges from behind the mandibular ramus. Lingual nerve is a branch from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it arcs around the submandibular duct. Ophthalmic nerve is a branch from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it arises in the middle cranial fossa.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. 2,3

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Correct Statements:
  • • Correct Statements:
  • • Statement 2 : True. The buccal branch, which is indeed a branch of the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, emerges from behind the mandibular ramus. This nerve primarily supplies sensory innervation to the skin over the cheek and buccal mucosa.
  • • Statement 2
  • • Statement 3: True. The lingual nerve, a branch from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve, is responsible for providing sensory innervation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. It famously arcs around the submandibular duct, a notable anatomical feature.
  • • Statement 3:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Statement 1 : Incorrect. The auriculotemporal nerve actually arises from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve, not the anterior division, and it does indeed emerge from behind the temporomandibular joint.
  • • Statement 1
  • • Statement 4: Incorrect. The ophthalmic nerve is not a branch of the mandibular nerve. Instead, it is an independent division of the trigeminal nerve (V1), originating from the trigeminal ganglion located in the middle cranial fossa. It is responsible for providing sensory innervation to the forehead, scalp, and parts of the eye.
  • • Statement 4:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The mandibular nerve's complex branching includes both sensory and motor components that are essential for facial sensation and movements. Understanding its branches, such as the buccal and lingual nerves, and their courses, is critical in dental, surgical, and diagnostic practices.
